facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 459 of 1965 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 459 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated July 14, 1964 of Punjab High Court in First Appeal from Order No.1 E of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 14, 1964 of the Punjab High Court in First Appeal from Order No.1 E of 1964. Bishan Narain, J. B. Dadachanji, O. C. Mathur and Ravinder Narain, for the appellants.

facts.text: General election held in 1962 for House of the People.

anchor.surface_text: In the general election held in 1962 for Parliament  House of the People , the appellant was elected from the Sangrur parliamentary. companystituency.

facts.text: Appellant was elected from Sangrur parliamentary constituency.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant was elected from the Sangrur parliamentary. companystituency. Pritam Singh respondent was also one of the companytesting candidates but lost in the election.

facts.text: Pritam Singh was a contesting candidate but lost the election.

anchor.surface_text: Pritam Singh respondent was also one of the companytesting candidates but lost in the election. Thereupon he filed an election petition against the appellant challenging his election on a number of grounds.

facts.text: Pritam Singh filed an election petition against the appellant challenging his election.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon he filed an election petition against the appellant challenging his election on a number of grounds. In the present appeal we are only companycerned with one ground, and that was that the numberination

facts.text: Ground of election petition: nomination papers of Wazir Singh rejected improperly by returning officer.

anchor.surface_text: In the present appeal we are only companycerned with one ground, and that was that the numberination papers of one of the candidates for the ,election, namely, Wazir Singh, had been rejected improperly by the returning officer. Wazir Singh had filed three numberination papers with one of them he had attached a companyy of a part of the electoral roll.

facts.text: Wazir Singh filed three nomination papers; one attached with copy of a part of the electoral roll, no such copy with the other two.

anchor.surface_text: Wazir Singh had filed three numberination papers with one of them he had attached a companyy of a part of the electoral roll. He attached numbersuch companyy with the other two numberination papers. When the numberination papers were being scrutinised, an objection was taken to the validity of the numberination papers.

facts.text: Returning officer rejected first nomination paper (with copy) because name of parliamentary constituency, village, assembly constituency, part number of candidate's electoral roll not mentioned, and proposer's parliamentary constituency not given.

anchor.surface_text: The returning officer first took up the numberination paper with which a companyy of part of the roll had been filed and rejected it on the ground that the name of the parliamentary companystituency and the name of the village and the assembly companystituency and the part number of the electoral roll of the candidate was number mentioned also because the name of the parliamentary companystituency  House of the People  of proposer was number given.

facts.text: Returning officer rejected the other two nomination papers because no copy of electoral roll or relevant part or certified entries filed with them.

anchor.surface_text: After rejecting this numberination paper, the returning offices took up the other two numberination papers and rejected them on the ground that a companyy of the electoral roll of the companystituency companycerned or of the relevant part thereof or a certified companyy of the relevant entries had number been filed along with these numberination papers.

facts.text: Returning officer refused to look into the copy filed with the first nomination paper when scrutinising the other two.

anchor.surface_text: It may be added that the returning officer refused to look into the companyy of the part of the roll which Wazir Singh had filed along with his numberination paper which the returning officer had already rejected before-he took up the other numberination papers.

facts.text: Pritam Singh contended that returning officer should have looked into the copy from first paper for scrutiny of others.

anchor.surface_text: The main companytention of respondent Pritam Singh in the election petition was that the returning officer was wrong in number looking into the companyy of the part of the roll which had been filed with the first numberination paper of Wazir Singh and that merely because that numberination paper had been rejected, the returning officer was number precluded from looking into the companyy of the part of the roll which had been produced with that numberination paper for the purpose of scrutiny of the other two numberination papers.

facts.text: Appellant contended nomination papers rightly rejected: copy required with each separately; copy should be of parliamentary constituency; copy was incomplete.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant on the other hand companytended that the numberination papers had been rightly rejected, and this companytention was based on three points raised on his behalf, namely- i  that a companyy of the electoral roll of that companystituency or a relevant part thereof or a certified companyy of the relevant entries of such roll should have been produced with each numberination paper separately  ii  in any case the companyy produced should have been of the parliamentary companystituency and  iii  that the companyy produced of the part of the roll was number a companyplete companyy and therefore was number a companypliance with the requirements of s. 33  5  of the Representation of the People Act, No. 43 of 1950,  hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: Election Tribunal held copy could be looked into but was incomplete, no compliance with s.33(5), rejection justified notwithstanding s.36(4).

anchor.surface_text: The Election Tribunal seems to have taken the view that the companyy filed along with the first numberination paper companyld number be looked into when the returning officer came to scrutinise the other numberination papers, even if it might be assumed to be a companyy of the parliamentary electoral roll. It further held that even if the companyy companyld be looked into, it was number a companyplete companyy and therefore there was numbercompliance with s. 33  5  of the Act and in companysequence the Tribunal held that the returning officer was justified in rejecting the numberination papers numberwithstanding the provisions of s. 36  4  of the Act.

facts.text: Pritam Singh appealed to Punjab High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Pritam Singh then went in appeal to the High Court.

facts.text: High Court held returning officer wrong not to look at copy; copy of assembly constituency sufficient for parliamentary; incomplete copy sufficient under s.33(5); one nomination paper improperly rejected, election result materially affected, set aside election.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the returning officer was wrong in number looking into the companyy which had been produced along with the first numberination paper, and that the companyy produced, though it was apparently of an assembly companystituency, companyld also be taken to be a companyy of the parliamentary roll. Lastly on the question whether the companyy produced was a companyplete companyy or number, the High Court held that the companyy actually produced, though it admittedly did number companytain certain pages, was sufficient for the purposes of s. 33  5  of the Act. In this view, the High Court held that one of the numberination papers of Wazir Singh was improperly rejected and in companysequence of that the result of the election was materially affected. It therefore set aside the election.

facts.text: High Court refused certificate; appellant obtained special leave from Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court having refused to grant a certificate, the appellant applied to this Court for special leave which was granted and that is how the matter has companye before us.

facts.text: Copy filed was not complete; appellant produced complete copy showing pages 19 to 22 and page 25 missing.

anchor.surface_text: It is number in dispute that the companyy filed was number a companyplete companyy. The appellant produced a companyplete companyy of that part of the roll and that showed that pages 19 to 22 and page 25 of that part of the roll were number filed by Wazir Singh.

facts.text: Copy was of Part IV of Simla legislative assembly electoral roll.

anchor.surface_text: The part in question produced in this case was part IV of the Simla legislative assembly electoral roll.

facts.text: Wazir Singh's name appeared in first amendment at No. 1853, but second amendment on page 25 not produced.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that in actual fact it appears from the companyy which was produced by the appellant before the Tribunal that Wazir Singhs name was number deleted in the second list of amendments but that appears from the companyy produced by the appellant before the Tribunal and number from the companyy produced by Wazir Singh before the returning officer.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, held nomination papers rightly rejected due to incomplete copy being substantial defect, dismissed election petition.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal therefore succeeds and is hereby allowed with companyts. The election petition is dismissed.

Mathur and Ravinder Narain, for the appellants. S. Shukla, for respondent No. 1. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Wanchoo,J.

issues.text: Whether the necessary copy required under s. 33(5) of the Act must be produced with every nomination paper, or is it sufficient if filed with one when multiple are filed

anchor.surface_text: In the first place it is urged that the necessary copy required under s. 33  5  of the Act must be produced with every nomination paper, and that it is not enough where more nomination papers than one are filed that a copy should have been filed with only one of them. Secondly it is urged that the copy produced was of the assembly

issues.text: Whether the copy produced should have been of the parliamentary (House of the People) constituency or is a copy of the assembly constituency sufficient

Lastly the argument is that in any case the copy produced was not complete and therefore there was no compliance with S. 33  5  of the Act. The returning officer therefore was justified

issues.text: Whether the copy produced was a complete copy of the relevant part and complied with s. 33(5), and whether the returning officer was justified in rejecting under s. 36(2)(b) notwithstanding s. 36(4)

anchor.surface_text: Lastly the argument is that in any case the copy produced was not complete and therefore there was no compliance with S. 33  5  of the Act. The returning officer therefore was justified in rejecting the nomination paper under S. 36  2   b  of the Act and that s. 36  4  did not apply in the circumstances of the case. We shall deal with these points seriatim.

issues.text: Whether the returning officer was precluded from looking into the copy filed with the first nomination paper (which was rejected) for scrutiny of the other nomination papers

anchor.surface_text: The main contention of respondent Pritam Singh in the election petition was that the returning officer was wrong in not looking into the copy of the part of the roll which had been filed with the first nomination paper of Wazir Singh and that merely because that nomination paper had been rejected, the returning officer was not precluded from looking into the copy of the part of the roll which had been produced with that nomination paper for the purpose of scrutiny of the other two nomination papers.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant on the other hand contended that the nomination papers had been rightly rejected, and this contention was based on three points raised on his behalf, namely- i that a copy of the electoral roll of that constituency or a relevant part thereof or a certified copy of the relevant entries of such roll should have been produced with each nomination paper separately ii in any case the copy produced should have been of the parliamentary constituency and iii that the copy produced of the part of the roll was not a complete copy and therefore was not a compliance with the requirements of s. 33 5 of the Representation of the People Act, No. 43 of 1951

anchor.surface_text: The Election Tribunal seems to have taken the view that the copy filed along with the first nomination paper could be looked into when the returning officer came to scrutinise the other nomination papers, even if it might be assumed to be a copy of the parliamentary electoral roll. It further held that even if the copy could be looked into, it was not a complete copy and therefore there was no compliance with s. 33 5 of the Act and in consequence the Tribunal held that the returning officer was justified in rejecting the nomination papers notwithstanding the provisions of s. 36 4 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the returning officer was wrong in not looking into the copy which had been produced along with the first nomination paper, and that the copy produced, though it was apparently of an assembly constituency, could also be taken to be a copy of the parliamentary roll. Lastly on the question whether the copy produced was a complete copy or not, the High Court held that the copy actually produced, though it admittedly did not contain certain pages, was sufficient for the purposes of s. 33 5 of the Act. In this view, the High Court held that one of the nomination papers of Wazir Singh was improperly rejected and in consequence of that the result of the election was materially affected.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed on looking into copy and assembly sufficient, rejected incomplete sufficient as substantial defect.

arguments.claim: Necessary copy under s.33(5) need not be produced with every nomination paper; sufficient if filed/produced with one or shown repeatedly.

anchor.surface_text: In the first place it is urged that the necessary copy required under s. 33 5 of the Act must be produced with every nomination paper, and that it is not enough where more nomination papers than one are filed that a copy should have been filed with only one of them. ... Section 33 5 does not require that a copy must be filed with each nomination paper for, the candidate is given the alternative to produce before the returning officer such copy at the time of the scrutiny.

arguments.claim: Copy of assembly constituency roll suffices for s.33(5) as parliamentary roll comprises assembly rolls within it.

anchor.surface_text: This brings us to the second point raised before us, namely, that the copy filed was not of the parliamentary House of the People constituency but of the assembly constituency. This contention also has no force. If we look at the Representation of the People Act, 1950 we find that Part III thereof provides for the preparation of electoral rolls for assembly constituencies. So far as parliamentary constituencies House of the People are concerned, s. 13D provides inter alia that the electoral roll for every parliamentary constituency shall consist of the electoral rolls of so much of the assembly constituencies as are comprised within that parliamentary constituency

arguments.claim: Incomplete copy of relevant part (missing pages/amendments) does not comply with s.33(5); constitutes substantial defect under s.36(4); justifies rejection under s.36(2)(b).

anchor.surface_text: It is not in dispute that the copy filed was not a complete copy. The appellant produced a complete copy of that part of the roll and that showed that pages 19 to 22 and page 25 of that part of the roll were not filed by Wazir Singh. ... To such a case S. 36 4 has no application. ... non-production of a complete copy of the relevant part in our opinion is a defect of a substantial character for it makes it impossible for the returning officer to decide whether the candidate is qualified or not.

holdings.text: It is sufficient under Section 33(5) to file or produce one copy of the electoral roll or relevant part for multiple nomination papers, and the returning officer is not precluded from considering the copy filed with one nomination paper (even if rejected) when scrutinising others.

anchor.surface_text: Then we come to s. 33  5 . The object of this provision obviously is to enable the returning officer to check whether the person standing for election is qualified for the purpose. The electoral roll of the constituency for which the returning officer is making scrutiny would be with him, and it is not necessary for a candidate to produce the copy of the roll of that constituency. But where the candidate belongs to another constituency the returning officer would not have the roll of that other constituency with him and therefore the provision contained in S. 33  5  has been made by the legislature to enable the returning officer to check that the candidate is qualified for standing for election.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation of s.33(5): object is verification of qualification; alternatives allow production at scrutiny without filing with each paper; no requirement for multiple copies; same copy can be shown repeatedly; purpose served by one copy even from rejected paper.

holdings.text: The returning officer was wrong in not looking at the copy filed with one nomination paper when dealing with other nomination papers of the same candidate.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore agree with the High Court that the returning officer was wrong in not looking at the copy filed with one nomination paper when he was dealing with other nomination papers of Wazir Singh.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Nothing in s.33(5) prevents RO from looking at copy from previously rejected paper; serves purpose of checking qualification.

holdings.text: A copy of the electoral roll of an assembly constituency comprised within the parliamentary constituency is sufficient under s.33(5) to show the candidate is an elector in the parliamentary constituency.

anchor.surface_text: This brings us to the second point raised before us, namely, that the copy filed was not of the parliamentary  House of the People  constituency but of the assembly constituency. This contention also has no force. If we look at the Representation of the People Act, 1950 we find that Part III thereof provides for the preparation of electoral rolls for assembly constituencies. So far as parliamentary constituencies  House of the People  are concerned, s. 13D provides inter alia that the electoral roll for every parliamentary constituency shall consist of the electoral rolls of so much of the assembly constituencies as are comprised within that parliamentary constituency

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory scheme: parliamentary electoral roll consists of assembly rolls within it (s.13D); copy of assembly roll thus proves elector status in parliamentary constituency.

holdings.text: Production of an incomplete copy of the relevant part of the electoral roll (missing pages including amendments) does not comply with s.33(5), constitutes a defect of substantial character, s.36(4) inapplicable, and justifies rejection of nomination papers under s.36(2)(b).

anchor.surface_text: It is not in dispute that the copy filed was not a complete copy. The appellant produced a complete copy of that part of the roll and that showed that pages 19 to 22 and page 25 of that part of the roll were not filed by Wazir Singh. Now s. 33  5  gives three options to a candidate in the matter of filing a copy. He may file either a copy of the electoral roll which means a copy of the entire electo- ral roll of the parliamentary  House of the People  constituency, or a copy of the relevant parts thereof, which means the whole of the parts concerned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Relevant part' means whole numbered part per r.5; must include all amendments per r.23(5) to verify current qualification; incomplete copy prevents RO from checking if name deleted; substantial defect as qualification is substantial matter; rejection proper even on other grounds.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal therefore succeeds and is hereby allowed with companyts. The election petition is dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal succeeds and is hereby allowed with costs; election petition is dismissed

The definition of 'elector' in Section 2(e) grounds the holding's determination of what constitutes sufficient proof that the candidate is an elector for nomination purposes under s.33(5).

anchor.surface_text: ompanystituency. But where the candidate belongs to another companystituency the returning officer would number have the roll of that other companysti

edges.explanation: The holding that one copy is sufficient under s.33(5) for multiple papers directly addresses and resolves the issue.

anchor.surface_text: Then we come to s. 33  5 . The object of this provision obviously is to enable the returning officer to check whether the person standing for election is qualified for the purpose. The electoral roll of the constituency for which the returning officer is making scrutiny would be with him, and it is not necessary for a candidate to produce the copy of the roll of that constituency. But where the candidate belongs to another constituency the returning officer would not have the roll of that other constituency with him and therefore the provision contained in S. 33  5  has been made by the legislature to enable the returning officer to check that the candidate is qualified for standing for election.
The appeal therefore succeeds and is hereby allowed with companyts. The election petition is dismissed.
We therefore agree with the High Court that the returning officer was wrong in not looking at the copy filed with one nomination paper when he was dealing with other nomination papers of Wazir Singh.
The appeal therefore succeeds and is hereby allowed with companyts. The election petition is dismissed.

edges.explanation: The holding directly resolves the issue by ruling that a copy of the assembly constituency electoral roll (comprised within the parliamentary constituency) is sufficient under s.33(5).

anchor.surface_text: This brings us to the second point raised before us, namely, that the copy filed was not of the parliamentary  House of the People  constituency but of the assembly constituency. This contention also has no force. If we look at the Representation of the People Act, 1950 we find that Part III thereof provides for the preparation of electoral rolls for assembly constituencies. So far as parliamentary constituencies  House of the People  are concerned, s. 13D provides inter alia that the electoral roll for every parliamentary constituency shall consist of the electoral rolls of so much of the assembly constituencies as are comprised within that parliamentary constituency
The appeal therefore succeeds and is hereby allowed with companyts. The election petition is dismissed.

edges.explanation: Holding h4 that incomplete copy is defect of substantial character grounds the concept c14 of substantial defect in nomination paper
Court holding h4 supports the tribunal's concept/interpretation c4 of s.33(5) requiring complete copy.
Holding h4 that incomplete copy does not comply with s.33(5) and justifies rejection addresses issue i3.

anchor.surface_text: It is not in dispute that the copy filed was not a complete copy. The appellant produced a complete copy of that part of the roll and that showed that pages 19 to 22 and page 25 of that part of the roll were not filed by Wazir Singh. Now s. 33  5  gives three options to a candidate in the matter of filing a copy. He may file either a copy of the electoral roll which means a copy of the entire electo- ral roll of the parliamentary  House of the People  constituency, or a copy of the relevant parts thereof, which means the whole of the parts concerned.
The appeal therefore succeeds and is hereby allowed with companyts. The election petition is dismissed.

edges.explanation: Issue i1 on sufficiency of one copy for multiple nominations addresses holding h1 resolving it affirmatively under s.33(5).

The issue questions the sufficiency of an assembly constituency electoral roll copy for parliamentary constituency purposes, directly engaging the definition of 'elector' under Section 2(e) as a person whose name is in the electoral roll of the constituency.
Issue i3 concerns whether the copy was a complete copy of the 'relevant part', which requires the definition of 'relevant part' as the whole part under Rule 5 (c12).
Issue i3 on whether copy complete/complied s.33(5) and justified rejection directly addresses substantial defect concept c14
Issue i3 on copy completeness and s.33(5) compliance addresses the concept c4 of non-compliance due to incomplete copy.
Resolving whether returning officer's rejection under s.36(2)(b) was justified notwithstanding s.36(4) requires the concept/interpretation of when s.36(4) does not apply.
The issue of s.33(5) compliance and substantial defect requires the holding determining that incomplete copy is a substantial defect.
